stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on implementing tutorial bunnies in Course 1 to teach players advanced movement techniques. The stream focused on iterating the tutorial's design from a simple coin grab to a more robust 'pass through the ring' challenge, creating the UI prompts, and programming the bunny's demonstration cutscene. The session was also an experiment to test YouTube as a streaming platform alternative to Twitch.

development_findings.summary: The primary focus of the stream was implementing tutorial bunnies in the first course to teach players the game's unique movement mechanics, such as the dive jump and spin jump.
development_findings.quote: We're going to add these tutorial bunnies to Course 1 that are going to teach you the movements.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is designing the tutorials to use visual prompts (icons in a speech bubble) instead of text pop-ups due to the N64's low resolution.
development_findings.quote: The N64 does not have the resolution for pop-up text.

development_findings.summary: Course 1 is highly optimized, running at nearly 60 FPS on original hardware, which gives the team freedom to add more visual details like trees without performance concerns.
development_findings.quote: This level here runs almost 60 FPS on N64, so we can add whatever we want to it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze continues to make engine-level optimizations, including to core math functions, to improve game performance.
development_findings.quote: I have done some more optimizations to the sine and cosine functions recently.

development_findings.summary: There is a known issue with Mario's lighting model appearing too dark, but a definitive solution has not been decided on yet.
development_findings.quote: I agree that Mario's a bit too dark in the ROM-Mac right now. And I do wanna improve that somehow, but I have not yet decided how that would happen.

development_findings.summary: The team has a flexible lighting system that allows them to easily bake new lighting conditions, such as changing the time of day or applying stylized color filters, directly in their tools.
development_findings.quote: You could even, if you wanted to, you could even like make this play in Mexico. Just setting the light to yellow. Now it's in Mexico. Or you could put this to night mode. Now it's night.

development_findings.summary: The design for the tutorial evolved from a simple 'jump to a coin' challenge to a more robust system where the player must pass through a particle-effect ring using a specific move, a solution proposed by Biobak to prevent 'cheesing' the tutorial.
Kaze implemented a system where climbable surface properties are used on walls to slow Mario's wall slide, making certain platforming sections easier and more forgiving.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes romhacks require extremely clear and concise design because players have no financial investment and thus less patience than they would for a commercial game.
context_findings.quote: For a romhack, you can't really go over your patience budget. Because with the romhack you have the disadvantage that no one paid for your game. So there's no initial commitment from the player.

context_findings.summary: Kaze describes the game development process as a cycle that begins with fun and inevitably becomes torturous, highlighting the high attrition rate for large fan projects.
context_findings.quote: That's the thing when you make games it always starts like really fun and eventually it turns into pure torture. That's just the cycle of making games.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is experimenting with streaming on YouTube as a potential alternative to Twitch, driven by his frustration with Twitch's aggressive and unavoidable ad policy.
context_findings.quote: I tried to use Twitch all throughout like last week to personally watch streams and it is so ad-riddled that I just can't stand it anymore. So I decided, hey, let's test out YouTube.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is highly critical of the original Mario 64's shadow system, viewing it as a major, easily fixable source of performance issues.
context_findings.quote: The Mario 64 object shadows are done so poorly. Like, if you are in Rainbow Ride and your game lags down to 25 FPS, a reasonably skilled programmer with like five minutes of time could have fixed the shadow system so that that runs at 30 FPS.

context_findings.summary: Kaze states the project will be open source once it is released.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided the key design solution for the tutorial bunnies, suggesting that players should have to perform the move through a ring to get the coin, preventing them from using other moves to bypass the lesson.
biobak.quote: But if there's a ring, you have to pass using the move. And if you do that, he gives you the coin.

biobak.summary: Biobak created and sent Kaze an improved version of the tutorial UI texture after Kaze struggled with the initial design.
Kaze mentioned that Biobak was responsible for a significant visual revamp of Course 1 to make it look prettier.

zeina.summary: Zeina is working on animations for the project, sharing a video of a Bowser animation with Kaze for feedback during the stream.
Zeina received specific feedback from Kaze on her Bowser animation, noting that the character's rotation point seemed incorrect.
zeina.quote: Like, the point where he's rotating is like here in the background.

key_stories.title: Designing the Tutorial Bunny System
key_stories.summary: The team needed a way to teach players new moves in Course 1. The initial idea was too easy to circumvent, so after feedback from Biobak, Kaze implemented a more robust system where players must perform the correct move through a special ring to get the reward, ensuring the tutorial is effective.
key_stories.challenge: How to create effective, non-intrusive tutorials for the game's new moves in the first level that players can't easily bypass with basic jumps.
key_stories.process: Kaze initially designed a simple challenge where a bunny demonstrates a move and the player must jump to a nearby coin. He quickly realized players could use a simple long jump to get the coin, defeating the purpose. After Biobak suggested using a ring that requires the specific move, Kaze pivoted the design, creating the particle effect for the ring and programming the logic for the bunny's cutscene and the reward condition.
key_stories.outcome: The team adopted Biobak's suggestion. The final design involves a bunny demonstrating a move, which then spawns a particle ring. The player only receives the collectible coin after successfully performing the correct move through the ring, ensuring the mechanic is learned.
key_stories.key_quote: But if there's a ring, you have to pass using the move. And if you do that, he gives you the coin. That feels like... I mean, it kind of works.

key_stories.title: Creating the Tutorial UI Prompt
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to create a clear and aesthetically pleasing UI prompt for the tutorials due to technical and artistic challenges. After several frustrating attempts to get it right, Biobak provided a superior, ready-to-use asset that solved the problem.
key_stories.challenge: To create a clear visual icon that teaches players multi-button moves (e.g., Z then A) while working within the N64's technical limitations, such as low resolution and indexed color palettes.
key_stories.process: Kaze attempted to create a speech bubble with button icons and an arrow. He struggled with image scaling artifacts, color indexing limitations that affected visual depth, and readability. He iterated on the design based on chat feedback, trying different layouts and styles, before Biobak stepped in with a professionally made alternative.
key_stories.outcome: After multiple attempts, Kaze created a functional placeholder texture. Biobak, seeing the struggle, created a more polished, multi-part texture asset for Kaze to implement, which was deemed a much better solution.
key_stories.key_quote: Oh my god, this is one of the oldest things made. Look how shit this looks. Let's fix it.
